entry.title: [MediaPicker]: Simplify the logging a bit.
entry.content:
We already have a metric that keeps track of the

upload count, but it is a bit too detailed to use

when evaluating the impact of making changes to the

upload flow, because it is also broken down into

how we determine the file type. That is too

cumbersome, because one has to pull the data out

to a separate spreadsheet (to add all the numbers

up). This gets rid of that need.

entry.title: Reland "Invalidation on stylesheet changes using selector matching"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit 5d12010188b8fd648efd2279956e8a6cbe20654e.

The revert has been in for ~6 hours and the tests in question still

fail on the Mac builders, so it's unlikely to be the culprit.

It also passes locally on Mac.



Original change's description:

> Invalidation on stylesheet changes using selector matching

>

> When inserting, deleting or modifying stylesheets, we need to invalidate

> style for some elements, even though the elements themselves did not

> change. Currently, we reuse the concept of InvalidationSets, which are

> mostly designed for changes to elements, for that. This can sometimes

> cause overbroad invalidations, especially if the style is written in

> a “modern” (read: less-than-ideal) fashion.

>

> We replace this by a somewhat slower but more precise and probably

> simpler system; for each candidate element in the DOM, we see if it

> matches any selectors in the old or the new rulesets (by means of

> the same bucketing logic we currently have during element rule

> collection), and if so, we mark it for style recalc. This isn't perfect;

> if we are e.g. adding a single rule to an existing stylesheet, we would

> still invalidate based on all rules in the sheet. We hope to improve

> this in a future patch, but even now, this shows significant

> improvements over most of blink_perf.css, with only a few regressions.

>

> Note that this means the experimental style invalidation information in

> devtools becomes somewhat less useful; it will no longer give reasons

> for invalidations when style sheets change. Fixing this would probably

> involve extending the protocol, although I haven't looked deeply into

> this.

>

> Bug: 1444522

> Change-Id: Ib95cf8d215bf4e7b58ab1955ebc1f3c7e31aead8

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4783456

> Commit-Queue: Steinar H Gunderson

> Reviewed-by: Adithya Srinivasan

> Reviewed-by: Rune Lillesveen

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1190433}



Bug: 1444522

entry.title: [delete autocomplete] Announce entry being deleted.
entry.content:
The accessibility reviewer has requested us to announce when the entry

is actually deleted, they made it a launch blocker.



about the implementation:

We had to move the announcement and metrics outside the cell.

This is due to the fact that after controller->RemoveSuggestion()

is called, the cell is deleted and any call after that can lead to

UAF.

entry.title: Avoid allocating RecordId objects in ElementTiming and LCP
entry.content:
RecordId objects in current code keep around references to LayoutObject

and ImageResourceContent, both GCed objects.

Turn out that most of these references are not needed and are only used

as hashmap keys that would be better served with an actual hash. The

ones that are needed don't need extensive lifetimes and can be stack

allocated.



Bug=1472365,1472366

entry.title: Don't add tree-scoped references to MPC
entry.content:
MatchedPropertiesCache could not re-use cache entries for shared

stylesheets across trees because tree-scoped names/references would be

resolved differently depending on tree-scope. We solved that by

including the TreeScope pointers in the hash key. However,

RemoveCachedMatchedPropertiesWithDeadEntries() would not be able to

clear out old entries from removed shadow tree if the stylesheet they

originated from still was in use in another tree-scope, leading to an

ever-growing MPC when e.g. web components were continuously added and

removed from the tree.



Instead, avoid the MPC completely if the matched properties contain

tree-scoped references.



TEST=wpt/css/css-anchor-position/anchor-name-in-shadow-002.html

entry.title: [SHv2] Stop relying on init behaviour of password infrastructure
entry.content:
Currently, the password status check module of SafetyHub relies on the

init logic of `SavedPasswordsPresenter` and `InsecureCredentialsManager`

for updating its cached numbers of weak and reused credentials.

This does not work when both profile and account store are active.

Instead, weak and reuse checks need to be called explicitly.

entry.title: Don't allow new line chars as preceding char for ::first-letter.
entry.content:
Because CR and LF new line chars belong to C* unicode category,

but allowed unicode categories as preceding chars are P* and Z*.



But in the context of WhiteSpaceCollapse::kCollapse,

space and new line chars are ignored,

so apply the behavior specified above only Blink::ShouldPreserveBreaks() is true.



Firefox 116.0.2 have this behavior,

but Safari 16.6 shows the same behavior with Chrome of before this change.



This change is per https://drafts.csswg.org/css-pseudo/#first-letter-pattern.

entry.title: Ignore specified CSS page size when not scaling to paper size.
entry.content:
When set up to fit print output to the paper size and CSS margins are to

be ignored, ignore CSS @page size as well, except for orientation. In

this mode the print output will not be scaled down to fit the page, so

if we honor @page sizes, and this is larger than the actual paper size,

the output would be clipped.



Add two component browser tests. The first one would fail without the

code changes here. The second one is there to verify that CSS-defined

page orientation is still honored.



Had to shuffle some code around in MockPrinter to make pixel tests work

in PrintRenderFrameHelperPreviewTest. It previously only worked in

PrintRenderFrameHelperTest, but I couldn't figure out how to set it up

to ignore margins there, with so-called "native" printing.

entry.title: [ios] Limit use of SessionIOS
entry.content:
The legacy session storage used to consist of a single SessionIOS object

containing exactly one SessionWindowIOS. This made the SessionIOS class

a bit redundant, so change the storage to be a SessionWindowIOS object.



Rename SessionIOSFactory to SessionWindowIOSFactory and change the API

of SessionServiceIOS to only expose SessionWindowIOS (thus the use of

SessionIOS is now limited to compatibility code in SessionServiceIOS).

entry.title: [ForceSigninVerifier] Ensure IdentityManger ref is freed
entry.content:
ForceSigninVerifier is owned by the ChromeSigninClient.

ForceSigninVerifier contains a reference to the IdentityManger.



IdentityManager indirectly depends on ChromeSigninClient, meaning that

we cannot add the regular DependsOn dependency, since it would create

a circular dependency between the factories.



The issue is that the IdentityManager is destroyed before the

ChromeSigninClient (order of dependency) which means ForceSigninVerifier

will hold an invalid reference to the IdentityManager.



---



The solution in this CL is to listen to the destruction of the

IdentityManager via the ShutDownNotifier service, and make it depend

on the IdentityManager.



There seems to be a bigger issue with the dependency between the

KeyedService Factories.



Change-Id: Ic9e8ac7e52b78c6ce00f88654b4765023e0bcc0e

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4822648

Commit-Queue: Ryan Sultanem

Reviewed-by: David Roger

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1190615}

entry.title: iwa: Fix IWA updates if a ServiceWorker has a fetch handler
entry.content:
It is important to bypass a potentially registered Service Worker during

IWA installation and updates:

1. Our mechanism to attach the location of the to-be-installed IWA to

the WebContents via `IsolatedWebAppPendingInstallInfo` is bypassed if

a Service Worker intercepts the requests in a fetch handler, because

such requests are not tied to any particular WebContents.

2. By ignoring Service Workers, we also prevent an IWA from maliciously

or accidentally tampering with our generated install page.



As part of this fix, I also updated the `WebAppUrlLoader` fakes to

overwrite the more generic `LoadUrl` method.



Bug: 1444407

entry.title: Remove PopupDelegate::OnPopupSuppressed.
entry.content:
The only use of this method was to emit UMA and UKM metrics to

measure Autofill popup suppression. However, these metrics have long

been broken, since they only measure the case in which the view can

(somehow) not be created. The more likely case of "the window area

is too small to show a popup" was not covered in these metrics.



This CL gets rid of the metric completely to simplify code.

Should it be needed, we can add it back.



Bug: 1007974

entry.title: Add an option to prioritize NavigationPreload
entry.content:
This CL adds a new feature param to ServiceWorkerAutoPreload, that

changes the behavior to respect NavigationPreload.



Before this CL, ServiceWorkerAutoPreload is prioritized over

NavigationPreload, but it may be better to respect NavigationPreload for

the compatibility purpose.



However, dispatching NavigationPreload should not be critical in most

cases, and this may make the AutoPreload impact being limited in terms

of the experiment. So, this CL implements it under the feature param to

monitor both.

entry.title: pip-pinch: Handle PiP pinch gesture started by client
entry.content:
This commit allows the client to initiate the pinch gesture.

When the target of a drag event is a client, ToplevelWindowEventHandler

does not initiate the drag and instead waits for the client to initiate

it. We have implemented the same feature to the pinch gesture. To

achieve this, 2 modifications were needed to be made:



1. AttemptToStartDrag, when called from client, now dispatches

AttemptToStartDrag or AttemptToStartPinch depending on the last gesture

recorded by ToplevelWindowEventHandler.



2. AttemptToStartPinch now transfers events from ExoSurface to

ExoShellSurface and updates gesture_target_ when called from the client.



Bug: b/295972987

entry.content:
This CL enables the calculation of the prompt edit state for

forgot password forms.

It also makes UFF-related code less confusing: many comments claim

that it's not possible to edit the saved credential in prompt on

Android, but it's not true after the launch of the password edit

dialog in 2022. This CL enables the prompt edit state calculation

on Android too, but does not enable sending votes yet.

fortunately it's not actually necessary to check it here -

GetActiveDataTypes().Has(HISTORY_DELETE_DIRECTIVES) is sufficient to

ensure that history is being sent to Google.

check for that again here.

entry.title: [BRP/clang-plugin] Determine bad cast exclusions in matchers
entry.content:
Create following matchers:

- isInStdBitCastHeader()

- isInRawPtrCastHeader()



Exclude if |isInRawPtrCastHeader()| or |isSpellingInSystemHeader()|

unless |isInStdBitCastHeader()|.

This should match old behavior written in naive-C++ |if|s.



Context: We may want to use it from a rewriter and want it to be in

RawPtrHelpers.h.

entry.title: Reland "[BRP/clang-plugin] Create BadRawPtrCastExpr matcher"
entry.content:
This reverts commit a77faebf83260fb435d7aa278f1370dbf605d1b7.



Reason for revert: crash fixed



See https://crrev.com/c/4825045/1..2 for diff between the original CL

and this reland. The return statement for `BadRawPtrCastExpr` was

missing, resulting in the crash.



Not related to the crash, but I changed |casting_unsafe_predicate|

parameter to const reference for tiny performance improvement.



Original change's description:

> Revert "[BRP/clang-plugin] Create BadRawPtrCastExpr matcher"

>

> This reverts commit e31e24a6c080c550880332b2fef72be9b92c0268.

>

> Reason for revert: Clang crashed at plugin tests on ToT* bots

>

> Original change's description:

> > [BRP/clang-plugin] Create BadRawPtrCastExpr matcher

> >

> > Create a function that returns a matcher for bad casting.

entry.title: VP9VaapiVED: Do not refresh frame context for consecutive key frames
entry.content:
It is a iHD-VP9 limitation that consecutive key frames must not refresh

the frame context to avoid corruption. This CL is a workaround forcing

'refresh_frame_context' to be false if the last encoded frame is a key

frame.

entry.title: Revert "[reland] content: unconditionally populate frame_url in ContextMenuParams"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 66321127ce9d3b926eb2949831d973fb8ef6e4c5.



Reason for revert: Break linux-chromeos-chrome



https://ci.chromium.org/ui/b/8771283259639514113



Original change's description:

> [reland] content: unconditionally populate frame_url in ContextMenuParams

>

> The prior design only populated frame_url when the initiating frame was

> a subframe, which led to code in quite a few places to use frame_url if

> present and page_url otherwise, or to test for an empty frame_url as a

> signal that the initiator was a subframe.

>

> This change makes frame_url unconditional, and adds a separate parameter

> for whether the initiator is a subframe. It also refactors

> TestRenderViewContextMenu slightly to make some of the factory arguments

> for that class optional, since nearly all call sites pass the same

> values.

>

> This is a preparatory refactor for a behavior change in passing invoker

> origins through the context menu.

>

> This change is a re-land of

> https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4790929,

> which introduced an MSan test failure because of the uninitialized

> is_subframe member in ContextMenuParams.

>

> Bug: 1457702

> Change-Id: I7980017b0333fdfe4b421b8e2feda1320d41db4f

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4790929

> Reviewed-by: Avi Drissman

> Reviewed-by: Nasko Oskov

> Reviewed-by: Łukasz Anforowicz

> Reviewed-by: Scott Violet

entry.title: Extend net::HttpAuthPreferences::AllowGssapiLibraryLoad() to Linux
entry.content:
GSSAPI library loading can't be available in a sandboxed network

service, so this CL extends AllowGssapiLibraryLoad() to Linux desktop.

AllowGssapiLibraryLoad() is also a useful signal that the user might

want kerberos in which case we will want to disable the Linux network

service sandbox (this is left to a future CL).



Change-Id: Ie44e855efa8c579345ed7bb8f7713a70088ada96

Bug: 1474362, 1079808

entry.title: Extend the loading phase duration from renderer scheduler
entry.content:
Currently the `MainThreadSchedulerImpl::ComputeCurrentUseCase`

returns `kEarlyLoading`/`kLoading` until all the main frames receives

FCP/FMP.



This loading phase timing may affect various performance metrics. For

example, `heap::ShouldOptimizeForLoadTime()` checks if the loading is

ongoing.



FMP happens before LCP, so the optimization won't cover the period

between FMP and LCP. This CL adds a variable buffer time after

receiving FMP so the loading phase is extended.



The buffer time will be controlled by feature param, and we will run

finch experiment to find out the best value that improves CWV most.



Bug: 1475646

Change-Id: I6318bc3f91e9e1c544f2207b71633c542f32221c

entry.title: Revert "Invalidation on stylesheet changes using selector matching"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 5d12010188b8fd648efd2279956e8a6cbe20654e.



Reason for revert: Speculative revert for breaking mac11,12,13

https://ci.chromium.org/ui/b/8771281724277921585

https://ci.chromium.org/ui/b/8771284467376453201

https://ci.chromium.org/ui/b/8771287407119542833





Original change's description:

> Invalidation on stylesheet changes using selector matching

>

> When inserting, deleting or modifying stylesheets, we need to invalidate

> style for some elements, even though the elements themselves did not

> change. Currently, we reuse the concept of InvalidationSets, which are

> mostly designed for changes to elements, for that. This can sometimes

> cause overbroad invalidations, especially if the style is written in

> a “modern” (read: less-than-ideal) fashion.

>

> We replace this by a somewhat slower but more precise and probably

> simpler system; for each candidate element in the DOM, we see if it

> matches any selectors in the old or the new rulesets (by means of

> the same bucketing logic we currently have during element rule

> collection), and if so, we mark it for style recalc. This isn't perfect;

> if we are e.g. adding a single rule to an existing stylesheet, we would

> still invalidate based on all rules in the sheet. We hope to improve

> this in a future patch, but even now, this shows significant

> improvements over most of blink_perf.css, with only a few regressions.

>

> Note that this means the experimental style invalidation information in

> devtools becomes somewhat less useful; it will no longer give reasons

> for invalidations when style sheets change. Fixing this would probably

> involve extending the protocol, although I haven't looked deeply into

> this.

>

> Bug: 1444522

> Change-Id: Ib95cf8d215bf4e7b58ab1955ebc1f3c7e31aead8

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4783456

> Commit-Queue: Steinar H Gunderson

> Reviewed-by: Adithya Srinivasan

> Reviewed-by: Rune Lillesveen

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1190433}



Bug: 1444522

Change-Id: I8cf2323c0adb47e6a1dc202f5e63e878b650a1d9

entry.title: Add tracing when prerendering does not reuse the initial RFH.
entry.content:
There are only a few situations when the initial RFH is not reused. Most

of these should not apply to prerendering (e.g. the forced browsing

instance swap when navigating to WebUI). The only known scenario when

prerendering would not reuse the initial RFH is dynamic isolation of

future BrowsingInstances on Android.



However, there seem to be instances in the wild where prerendering is

not reusing the initial RFH outside of Android. Add some tracing to

better understand this situation (which currently also leads to a

browser <-> renderer state mismatch).

entry.content:

fullscreen, and makes client explicitly set CanFullscreen in addition

to CanMaximize.



This *should* not have any user observable changes, because I simply

invoked a SetFullscreen at places where SetCanMaximize are called. This

CL does potentially invoke additional OnSizeConstraintChanged callbacks,

which might have an impact on certain platforms (e.g. Mac and Lacros).

entry.title: Prevent immersive XR sessions from processing inline data
entry.content:
There is sometimes a race which causes the "last" inline frame data

before an immersive session is started to be sent to the immersive

session. If the immersive session supplies its first set of requested

frame data before the session processes the frame, this can result in

two frames being processed for the inline session for the same frame id.

This can result in either a hung session or a crash depending on the

device implementation (prior to https://crrev.com/c/4824564 Cardboard

for instance would hang, but after it a mojo disconnect and subsequent

tab crash would be triggered). While a more thorough fix will

re-evaluate the usage of the frame_id_ member, this initial patch to

ensure that the immersive session doesn't try (and usually fail) to

operate on the last set of inline frame data appears to mitigate the

issue.



Bug: 1477016

Change-Id: I565f2d5418d6f0900e711b768da59e95829880c8

entry.content:

it is cleared often. This causes unneeded dladdr lookups during

tracing. TLS data storage was added to perfetto SDK so we could

add a module cache per TraceEventDataSource.

entry.title: Anchored Nudge Dismiss Animation
entry.content:
Call `Hide()` instead of `CloseNow()` when dismissing nudges to trigger

a fade-out animation, and observe when this animation is completed to

close and destroy the nudge widget.



`CloseNow()` still needs to be called when we need to close nudges

without triggering their hide animation e.g. when shutting down, adding

a nudge pause or replacing a nudge.



video: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1IDLq7Y8KqlnHosbssirFA0i4X8hWTukJ/view?usp=drive_link&resourcekey=0-VQG20bJ27rbY8W8xjkh3Gw

entry.title: Reduce timeout for Crostini DLC installation when already installed
entry.content:
The DLC step should be instant if Crostini has already been installed,

but to allow for a slow response, set the timeout to 5 minutes.



Also reduce the timeout for the configure stage to 5 seconds, it

should only be reached for multi-container installs. This means if this

gets broken at some point, the install will actually finish in a

reasonable amount of time.



As per b/205650706 there are a couple of cases where Crostini is

installed not via the installer (or multi-container install flow). These

cases should be fairly uncommon and will now fail if DLC installation

takes over 5 minutes.



Bug: b/268127930

Change-Id: I7b587bfe2ce1b937c92baee32456c51941da580e

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4823591

entry.title: Discovery: Pass Profile into ARC RecommendedAppsFetcher
entry.content:
AppDiscoveryService is already owned by a Profile, so we should use that

for all profile-keyed operations. This avoids the need to look up the

Profile via ProfileManager, which is an awkward dependency in the

BUILD.gn structure.



Bug: 1475504

entry.title: [uia] Fix for `Compare` and `IsEmbeddedObjectInParent`
entry.content:
This CL addresses a bug where an AT was trying to navigate by character

in a text marked with aria-invalid="spelling" and it was not announcing

the characters after the first one.



There were two roots for this behavior.



1. `TextRangeProvider::Compare` was not using the newly introduced

`kUIAExposeForTextContent` embedded object enum, which caused some

comparisons down the pipeline to do incorrect computations using

IA2's hypertext instead of UIA's.



2. After this was fixed, there was an issue in

`IsEmbeddedObjectInParent`. Before this patch, the behavior was the same

for both `kUIAExpose...`and `kExpose...`. This was incorrect for UIA,

because the hypertext for a node is the text contents of ALL the children,

not just the first one.

So to know if it should be represented by embedded obj in parent we

have to essentially return `GetText(UIAExpose) == embedded_obj_str`.





Bug: 1474000

Change-Id: I456d75f029d9ed519a70ec73701a7ea214ca65e4

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4827371

Commit-Queue: Javier Contreras

entry.title: media/video/Vp9Metadata: Add active spatial layer begin/end index
entry.content:
A hardware encoder should report libwebrtc to the spatial layer

indices based on the initially configured spatial layers, not the

current spatial layers. This CL reports the active spatial layer range

as begin and end index in the metadata. This is easier than changing

the code in hardware encoders implementation to produce a spatial

layer index that start with non-zero.

entry.title: Fix leak in SelectFileDialogLinuxPortal
entry.content:
Both SelectFileDialogLinuxPortal and DialogInfo were getting leaked.

This is due to a reference cycle caused by

SelectFileDialogLinuxPortal keeping a scoped_refptr to the DialogInfo,

while the DialogInfo keeps 2 callbacks that bind to

SelectFileDialogLinuxPortal methods. This CL breaks the reference

cycle by switching the callbacks to use weak pointers. However,

DialogInfo is still leaked with this change because dbus::Bus also

has callbacks that bind do DialogInfo, so these are changed to weak

pointers as well.



R=sky



Bug: None

Change-Id: I4ee11c67f2181b2ec8cdbefdf2536e89116a42c4

Low-Coverage-Reason: Currently no tests for SelectFileDialogLinuxPortal
